snippet: Across the Continent, as in the United States, the virus has stirred a wave of alarm that, according to experts, reflects the insecurities of the modern mind far more than any significant danger to public health.
abstract: Across Europe, as in United States, Ebola virus has infected only a handful of people, all of them medical workers in hospitals treating infected patients; regardless of small numbers, occurrences have spurred alarm that doctors and psychologists say reflects insecurities of modern mind far more than any significant danger to public health.

byline.contributor: Raphael Minder contributed reporting from Madrid, Elisabetta Povoledo from Rome, and David M. Herszenhorn from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: Across the Continent, as in the United States, the virus has stirred a wave of alarm that, according to experts, reflects the insecurities of the modern mind far more than any significant danger to public health.

headline.main: In Europe, Fear of Ebola Exceeds the Actual Risks
headline.print_headline: In Europe, Fear of Ebola Exceeds the Actual Risks
